questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with symptoms suggestive of a metabolic disorder. Biochemical tests are performed to analyze protein structures and their carbohydrate components. The medical team needs to differentiate between glycoproteins and proteoglycans to better understand the patient’s condition. Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: Proteoglycans have long mucopolysaccharide chains and high carbohydrate content.
Glycoproteins have long mucopolysaccharide chains and higher carbohydrate content
Proteoglycans contain short oligosaccharide chains and lower carbohydrate content

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Proteoglycans have long mucopolysaccharide chains and are characterized by their high carbohydrate content.

Explanation: Proteoglycans contain long mucopolysaccharide chains, are negatively charged due to sulfated or acetylated groups, and have higher carbohydrate content compared to glycoproteins, which have shorter oligosaccharide chains and are less negatively charged.


 

Property

Glycoproteins

Proteoglycans

Carbohydrates content

Low

High

Basic difference

Oligosaccharide chain

Mucopolysaccharide chain

Charge

Not negatively charged
  • Negatively charged
  • sulfated or acetylated

Location
  • Plasma proteins
  • Cellular receptors – except albumin
  • Receptors made up of simple proteins can not be heterogenous, as simple proteins are made up of just 2- aminoacids which can be linked by peptide linkages. Lack of heterogeneity causes lack of specificity
  • ECM - extracellular matrix

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents because she is more fatigued than usual and frequently thirsty. A urinalysis reveals positive results for Benedict's test, Barfoed's test, and Glucose Oxidase Peroxidase Test are also positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Lactose due to pregnancy and lactation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diabetes Mellitus

Explanation:

The most probable diagnosis, considering the symptoms and test results, is Diabetes Mellitus, indicated by the presence of glucose as a reducing monosaccharide in the urine. The positive results in both Benedict’s and Barfoed’s tests support this conclusion. It is further verified by a positive Glucose Oxidase Peroxidase Test (GOD-POD).

Algorithm for detecting sugars in urine:

 

Test

Purpose

Interpretation

Benedict's Test

Detects reducing substances in urine.

Positive indicates presence of reducing sugars, but not specific for monosaccharides.

Barfoed's Test

Differentiates between reducing monosaccharides and other sugars.

Positive indicates reducing monosaccharides (e.g., glucose, fructose, galactose).

Glucose Oxidase Peroxidase Test (GOD-POD)

Specifically tests for glucose presence.

Positive confirms glucose, supporting diagnosis of diabetes mellitus.

Seliwanoff Test

Distinguishes ketoses like fructose from aldoses like glucose.

Positive indicates fructose; observed in essential fructosuria if combined with other symptoms.

Mucic Acid Test

Identifies galactose in the urine.

Positive confirms galactose, supporting a diagnosis of classical galactosemia.

Bial's Test

Identifies pentoses in the urine.

Used for diagnosing conditions like essential pentosuria.

Other options:

Essential Fructosuria (Option B) would show a negative Glucose Oxidase Peroxidase Test test.

Lactose due to pregnancy and lactation (Option C) would show a negative Barfoed's test, and generally would have history and features of pregnancy.

Classical Galactosemia (Option D) would also show a negative Glucose Oxidase Peroxidase Test test.

questions.text: A laboratory technician performs an Osazone test on a patient's urine sample and observes the formation of characteristic crystals. The results show the presence of fluffy, hedgehog-shaped crystals. Which sugar is most likely present in the urine sample?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lactose

Explanation: The Osazone test is used to differentiate reducing sugars based on the unique shapes and formation times of crystals. Lactose forms Hedgehog or “Pincushion with pins” or “flower of touch-me-not plant” shaped Lactosazones, with an excess of Phenylhydrazine when kept at boiling temperature.

 

Sugar

Crystal Shape

Notes

Lactose

(Option B)

Hedgehog or “Pincushion with pins” or “flower of touch-me-not plant”

 

Indicates lactose presence, as seen in galactosemia.

Glucose (Option A)

 

Fructose

Needle-shaped crystals arranged like a broom

Often associated with conditions like Diabetes Mellitus.

Maltose

(Option C)

 

 

Sunflower-shaped or Petal-shaped

Takes longer time to form, associated with menopausal status in women.

Sucrose

(Option D)

No crystals

Sucrose is a non-reducing sugar and does not form crystals in the Osazone test.

questions.text: What is the reagent used in Barfoed’s test to detect monosaccharides?

choices.text: Sodium carbonate, copper sulfate, and sodium citrate
Cupric acetate in acetic acid solution

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Cupric acetate in acetic acid solution

Explanation:

  • Barfoed’s test is used to distinguish between monosaccharides and disaccharides.
  • The reagent used is cupric acetate in an acetic acid solution.
  • It is weakly acidic and is reduced by only monosaccharides.
  • A false positive result can occur with prolonged boiling of disaccharides.
  • Monosaccharides react with this reagent within 5 minutes to give a brick-red precipitate of copper (I) oxide.
  • Disaccharides take a longer time to react because the aldehyde function is masked in the acetal linkage and gives an orange-red color.

questions.text: A new mother comes to the pediatric OPD with her infant as she notices dark staining in diapers after the baby urinates. What is the possible enzyme defect here?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Homogentisic acid oxidase

Explanation:

  • The scenario here points to Alkaptonuria which is an autosomal recessive condition.
  • Caused due to deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase leading to excretion of homogentisic acid through urine.
  • Investigations:

Urine becomes darker on standing: blackening is accelerated on exposure to sunlight and oxygen. In a test tube urine starts blackening from the top layer.

Ferric chloride test: positive (urine)

Benedict’s test: strongly positive, screening test. Can be a differential diagnosis for reducing sugars in urine.

 

Enzyme

Disease

Option A) Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase

Tyrosinemia type I

Option B) Homogentisic acid oxidase

Alkaptonuria

Option C) Cystathionine β-synthase

Homocystinuria

Option D) Phenylalanine hydroxylase

Phenylketonuria

questions.text: A urine sample of a diabetes patient was tested to see the presence of reducing sugars in the laboratory. Initial color of solution is blue. What would be the color of the solution after the test?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Orange

Explanation:

  • The presence of reducing sugars is detected by Benedict’s test which is a blue solution that turns its color in the range from green to yellow to orange to red according to the concentration of the reducing sugars.
  • A positive Benedict’s test: change in color from blue to green/yellow/orange/red

A negative Benedict’s test: no change in color.

  • The reagent here is Benedict's solution which contains sodium carbonate, copper sulphate, and sodium citrate. The copper sulfate gives it a blue color.
  • In an alkaline medium, sugars form enediol that in turn reduces the cupric ions in the reagent. This changes the color of the reagent.
  • Any sugar with a free aldehyde or keto group will reduce the Benedict’s reagent and hence this is not a reliable test for detecting glucose in urine.
  • Disaccharides like sucrose don't react with the reagent as such but only after hydrolysis of sucrose does it give a positive test result. This is a specific test for detecting sucrose.
  • Interpretation of Benedict’s test:

questions.text:
A 55-year-old female patient presents with symptoms of increased thirst, frequent urination, and weight loss. The physician suspects diabetes mellitus and decides to test the patient's urine for reducing sugars using Benedict's and Fehling's solutions. Below are images of the test results.

Image A: Benedict's Test Results 

Image B: Fehling's Test Results



 

Based on the images provided, which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: Both tests indicate the absence of reducing sugars in the urine sample.
Both tests indicate the presence of reducing sugars in the urine sample.
Benedict's test indicates the presence of reducing sugars, while Fehling's test indicates their absence.
Benedict's test indicates the absence of reducing sugars, while Fehling's test indicates their presence.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Both tests indicate the presence of reducing sugars in the urine sample.

 

Explanation:

Image A (Benedict's Test Results):

The color changes from blue to green, yellow, and red, indicating the presence of reducing substances in the urine sample.

Image B (Fehling's Test Results)

The color changes from blue to brick-red, indicating the presence of reducing substances in the urine sample.

 

Therefore, both tests confirm the presence of reducing sugars, which may suggest a condition like diabetes mellitus in the patient.

questions.text: Which type of isomerism is exhibited by these two compounds?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Functional Isomerism

Explanation:

The given structures are that of Glucose and Fructose, which are examples of functional isomers. They have the same molecular formula but differ in their functional groups, with glucose being an aldehyde (aldohexose) and fructose being a ketone (ketohexose).

 

Explanation of Isomerism Types:

Type of Isomerism

Description

Examples

Functional Isomerism

Compounds with the same molecular formula but different structural formulas, specifically due to different functional groups.

Glucose (an aldehyde) and Fructose (a ketone)

Epimerism (Option B)

Compounds differing in configuration around just one chiral carbon atom.

D-Glucose and D-Mannose are epimers because they differ at the C-2 carbon.

Enantiomerism (Option C)

Compounds that are non-superimposable mirror images, differing at all chiral centers.

L-Glucose and D-Glucose are enantiomers, being mirror images of each other

Anomerism (Option D)

Compounds differing at the anomeric carbon formed during the ring closure of carbohydrates.

α-D-Glucose and β-D-Glucose differ in configuration at the anomeric carbon (C-1)

questions.text: Xylose and arabinose are examples of?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Diastereoisomerism

 

Explanation:

  • Xylose and Arabinose are both aldopentoses (five-carbon sugars with an aldehyde group).

  • They differ at two stereocentres: typically C-2 and C-3.

  • Since diastereomers differ at one or more (but not all) chiral centres and are not mirror images, xylose and arabinose qualify as diastereoisomers, not epimers.

 

 

 

Optical Isomerism (Option A): Two molecules with same molecular formula, but differ in the way they turn the plain polarised lights.

  • The orientation of the —H an —OH groups around the carbon atom adjacent to the terminal alcohol carbon (carbon 5 in glucose) etermines whether the sugar beongs to the d or l series.
  • The isomer that turns the light to the right side is called dextrorotatory (d/ +)
  • The isomer that turns the light to the right side is called Levorotatory (l / -)

 

Enantiomerism (Option C): Exact mirror image of the carbon atoms. Another name for enantiomerism is Racemism.

 

Epimerism (Option D): Epimers differ at only one chiral centre. Since xylose and arabinose differ at two chiral centres, they are not epimers.

questions.text: Which type of isomerism involves two molecules that have the same molecular formula and structural formula but differ in the spatial arrangement of their groups?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Stereoisomerism

 

Explanation:

Stereoisomerism: A broad category of isomerism where molecules have the same molecular formula and connectivity of atoms but differ in the spatial arrangement of their atoms.

 

Optical Isomerism: (Option A)

  • Here the two molecules have the same molecular formula, but they differ in the way they turn the plane polarized light.
  • The orientation of the —H and —OH groups around the carbon atom adjacent to the termina alcohol carbon (carbon 5 in glucose) determines whether the sugar belongs to the d or l series.
  • The isomer that turns the light to the right side is called Dextrorotatory (d/ +)
  • The isomer that turns the light to the left side is called Levorotatory (l / -)
  • Example: Lactic acid, which exists as two enantiomers: L-lactic acid and D-lactic acid.

·

Functional Isomerism: (Option B)

  • Two molecules have the same molecular formula but different functional groups.
  • Example: Ethanol (an alcohol) and dimethyl ether (an ether) both have the formula C2H6O but different functional groups and properties.

questions.text: Identify the type of linkage in the given Structure.
questions.solution:
Correct answer- a) O-linked Glycoproteins

Explanation

 

O-linked glycoproteins

(post-translation modification)
  • Carbohydrate chains are attached to the oxygen atom of serine or threonine residues.
  • Mucins: Major components of mucus, providing lubrication and protection to epithelial surfaces.
  • Glycoproteins in collagen

N-linked glycoproteins

(Option B)
  • Carbohydrate chains are attached to the nitrogen atom of asparagine residues.
  • Immunoglobulins (IgG) & Erythropoietin

GPI anchored Glycoproteins

(Option C)
  • Carbohydrates are not attached to any amino acid
  • Anchor consists of a lipid tail (phosphatidylinositol) and a glycan chain, which covalently links the protein to the membrane.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with symptoms of fatigue, abdominal pain, and dark-coloured urine, especially noticed in the morning. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of hemoglobinuria. Which of the following tests is most appropriate for confirming a diagnosis of Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Flow Cytometry

 

Explanation:

Flow cytometry is used to detect the absence or reduced expression of surface proteins CD55 and CD59 on red blood cells. These proteins are typically absent or deficient in PNH due to the genetic mutation affecting their GPI anchors.

 

Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH):

A rare, acquired blood disorder characterized by the destruction of red blood cells due to a genetic mutation affecting cell membrane protection.

 

Cause:

  • Mutation in the PIGA gene.
  • Defective synthesis of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors, which are crucial for attaching protective proteins to red blood cells.

 

Key Proteins Involved:

  • CD55 (Decay Accelerating Factor): Prevents complement system activation on the red blood cell surface.
  • CD59 (Membrane Inhibitor of Reactive Lysis) inhibits the formation of the complement system's membrane attack complex.

 

Bone Marrow Biopsy(Option A): This test is used to diagnose various bone marrow disorders but is not specific for PNH.

Serum Ferritin Test(Option C): This test measures iron storage levels and is not specific to PNH. It is more useful for diagnosing iron-related disorders.

Haemoglobin Electrophoresis(Option D): This test separates different types of haemoglobin but does not diagnose PNH. It is used to diagnose hemoglobinopathies such as sickle cell disease or thalassemia.

questions.text: Which category of carbohydrates consists of molecules that cannot be hydrolyzed into simpler sugars?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Monosaccharides

Explanation:

Monosaccharides are simple carbohydrates made up of single carbohydrate units and hence cannot be hydrolysed.

Carbohydrates are divided into simple and complex carbohydrates.

Simple carbohydrates can further be classified as follows:

 

Type

Feature

Monosaccharides

Single carbohydrate unit in them

Ex: glucose, fructose

Disaccharides

Two monosaccharide units

Ex: sucrose, maltose, isomaltose, trehalose, lactose

Oligosaccharides

3- 10 monosaccharide units

Ex: Maltotriose

Polysaccharides

More than 10 monosaccharide units

Ex: starch, cellulose, glycogen

questions.text: Which of the following statements is a distinguishing feature between Hunter syndrome and Hurler syndrome?

choices.text: Hunter syndrome is associated with corneal clouding; Hurler is not.
Hurler syndrome is due to a deficiency in iduronate-2-sulfatase; Hunter syndrome is due to a deficiency in alpha-L-iduronidase.
Both syndromes result in the accumulation of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate.
Hunter syndrome is X-linked recessive; Hurler syndrome is autosomal recessive.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hunter syndrome is X-linked recessive; Hurler syndrome is autosomal recessive.

Explanation:

Hunter syndrome arises due to a lack of the enzyme iduronate-2-sulfatase and follows an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern. In contrast, Hurler syndrome is due to a deficiency in the enzyme alpha-L-iduronidase and is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner (Option B).

Both disorders result in the buildup of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate in tissues (Option C). However, corneal clouding, which is observed in Hurler syndrome, is not typically seen in Hunter syndrome (Option A).

Differentiating Features of Hurler and Hunter Syndromes

Feature

Hurler Syndrome (MPS I)

Hunter Syndrome (MPS II)

Deficient Enzyme

L-Iduronidase

Iduronate sulfatase

Inheritance (Option D)

Autosomal recessive

X-linked recessive

Mental Retardation

Severe (MR+++)

Mild to moderate (MR+)

Corneal Opacity

Present (Corneal opacity++)

Absent (No corneal clouding)

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with developmental delay, behavioural problems, and progressive mental deterioration. Physical examination reveals coarse facial features and hepatosplenomegaly, his ocular findings are normal. The paediatrician suspects a type of mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS). Based on these clinical features, which kind of MPS is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) MPS III (Sanfilippo syndrome)

Explanation:

MPS III, also known as Sanfilippo syndrome, is the most common type of mucopolysaccharidosis. It is characterized by severe central nervous system involvement leading to progressive mental deterioration, behavioral problems, and developmental delay.

Clinical Features and Investigations of Mucopolysaccharidoses

Disease Name

Abbreviation

Enzyme Defective

GAG(s) Affected

Symptoms

Hurler, Scheie, Hurler-Scheie syndrome

(Option A)

MPS I

α-L-Iduronidase

Dermatan sulfate, heparan sulfate

Mental retardation, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, cloudy cornea

Hunter syndrome

MPS II

Iduronate sulfatase

Dermatan sulfate, heparan sulfate

Mental retardation

Sanfilippo syndrome A

(Option C)

MPS IIIA

Heparan sulfate-N-sulfatase

Heparan sulfate

Delay in development, motor dysfunction

Sanfilippo syndrome B

MPS IIIB

α-N-Acetylglucosaminidase

Heparan sulfate

As MPS IIIA

Sanfilippo syndrome C

MPS IIIC

α-Glucosaminide N-acetyltransferase

Heparan sulfate

As MPS IIIA

Sanfilippo syndrome D

MPS IIID

N-Acetylglucosamine 6-sulfatase

Heparan sulfate

As MPS IIIA

Morquio syndrome A

(Option D)

MPS IVA

Galactosamine 6-sulfatase

Keratan sulfate, chondroitin 6-sulfate

Skeletal dysplasia, short stature

Morquio syndrome B

MPS IVB

β-Galactosidase

Keratan sulfate

Skeletal dysplasia, short stature

Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome

MPS VI

N-Acetylgalactosamine 4-sulfatase

Dermatan sulfate

Curvature of the spine, short stature, skeletal dysplasia, cardiac defects

Sly syndrome

MPS VII

β-Glucuronidase

Dermatan sulfate, heparan sulfate, chondroitin 4-sulfate, chondroitin 6-sulfate

Skeletal dysplasia, short stature, hepatosplenomegaly, cloudy cornea

Natowicz syndrome (Option B)

MPS IX

Hyaluronidase

Hyaluronic acid

Joint pain, short stature

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms indicative of joint issues, including pain and reduced mobility. Examination reveals that the patient's synovial fluid is lacking a key mucopolysaccharide responsible for lubrication. Which mucopolysaccharide is most likely deficient in this patient's synovial fluid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hyaluronic Acid

Explanation:

Hyaluronic acid is predominantly found in connective tissues, tendons, synovial fluid, and the vitreous humor of the eye. It serves as a crucial lubricant in joint cavities, helping to maintain joint health and mobility. A deficiency in hyaluronic acid can lead to joint pain and reduced mobility due to insufficient lubrication in the synovial fluid.

Functions of Various Mucopolysaccharides

Mucopolysaccharide

Functions

Hyaluronic Acid

(Option D)

Serves as a lubricant in joint cavities and contributes to the structure of connective tissues

Heparin

(Option A)

Acts as an anticoagulant by activating antithrombin III, which inactivates thrombin and other clotting factors

Chondroitin Sulfate

(Option B)

Provides structural support to connective tissues and contributes to their resilience and elasticity

Dermatan Sulfate

(Option C)

Contributes to the structure of the skin, blood vessels, and heart valves

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with a rare genetic disorder affecting the structural integrity of their skin and blood vessels, resulting in hyperextensible skin and increased susceptibility to vascular damage. Which mucopolysaccharide is present in the skin and blood vessels, most likely involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Dermatan Sulfate

 

Explanation:

Dermatan sulfate contributes to the structure of the skin, blood vessels, and heart valves. A deficiency or dysfunction in dermatan sulfate can lead to issues with the structural integrity of the skin and blood vessels, resulting in symptoms such as hyperextensible skin and increased vascular fragility.

 

Locations of Various Mucopolysaccharides:

Mucopolysaccharide

Primary Locations

Hyaluronic Acid (Option A)

Connective tissues, tendons, synovial fluid, vitreous humor

Heparin (Option B)

Liver, lungs, spleen, monocytes

Chondroitin Sulfate (Option C)

Cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea, skin

Keratan Sulfate

Cornea, cartilage

Dermatan Sulfate (Option D)

Skin, blood vessels, heart valves

questions.text: Analyse the structure of the mucopolysaccharide shown below: Which mucopolysaccharide is represented in this image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Keratan sulfate

Explanation:

The image depicts Keratan sulfate, identifiable by its unique composition of galactose and N-acetylglucosamine, along with possible sulfate groups. It is unique among glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) because it lacks uronic acid​. It is primarily found in the cornea and cartilage, contributing to their structural properties​.

Identification Tips:

  • Look for the presence of galactose as one of the primary sugars in the disaccharide unit.
  • N-acetylglucosamine can be identified by the presence of the N-acetyl group (CH₃CONH).
  • Sulfate groups may be attached to either of the sugar moieties, contributing to the molecule's negative charge.

Mucopolysaccharide (MPS)

Components

Keratan Sulfate

Galactose and N-acetylglucosamine

Heparan Sulfate (Option A)

Glucuronic acid (or iduronic acid) and N-sulfated glucosamine

Dermatan Sulfate (Option D)

Iduronic acid and N-acetylgalactosamine

Chondroitin Sulfate (Option C)

Glucuronic acid and N-acetylgalactosamine

Hyaluronic Acid

Glucuronic acid and N-acetylglucosamine

questions.text: Mucopolysaccharides are heteropolysaccharides containing uronic acid and amino sugars. Which among the following mucopolysaccharides contradicts the above statement?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Keratan sulfate

Explanation:

Keratan sulfate is unique among mucopolysaccharides as it is the only GAG that does not contain any uronic acid.


 

Keratan sulfate

(Option A)

Repeating units are galactose and N-acetyl glucosamine in beta linkage.

Chondroitin sulfate

(Option B)

Repeating units of glucuronic acid → beta-1,3-N-acetyl galactosamine sulfate → beta-1,4 and so on.

Dermatan sulfate

(Option C)

It Contains L-iduronic acid and N-acetyl galactosamine in beta-1, 3 linkages.

Heparin

(Option D)
  • An anticoagulant widely used
  • Repeating units of sulphated glucosamine → alpha-1, 4-L-iduronic acid → and so on
  • Iduronic acid is the oxidized form of idose.

questions.text: Which of the following is accurate about dietary fibres?

choices.text: Insoluble fibre is fermented in the large intestine
Dietary fibre provides a significant source of energy
Soluble fibre helps lower LDL cholesterol

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Soluble fiber helps lower LDL cholesterol

Explanation:

 

Soluble fiber

Insoluble fiber
  • Lower LDL cholesterol levels by increasing bile acid excretion and interfering with bile acid reabsorption
  • Fermented in the large intestine to short-chain fatty acids (Option A)
  • Ex: Oats, barley, psyllium, brussel sprouts, etc
  • Adds bulk and promotes bowel movements. (Option D)
  • Passes through the digestive tract largely unchanged (Option A)
  • Ex: whole wheat, walnuts, chickpeas, etc


 

Dietary fibre is the non-digestible, non-starch carbohydrate and lignin present intact in plants.

 

Dietary fibre does not provide much energy but provides other benefits. It adds bulk to the diet, leads to early satiety, reduces blood glucose spikes after a meal, lowers total cholesterol and LDL, and reduces constipation, haemorrhoids and diverticulosis.(Option B)

questions.text: Which of the following pairs correctly distinguishes between homoglycans and heteroglycans?

choices.text:
Homoglycans - repeated units of the same monosaccharide;

Heteroglycans - two or more different types of monosaccharide units.
Homoglycans - used for structural purposes; Heteroglycans - energy storage.
Homoglycans- typically soluble in water; Heteroglycans - insoluble.
Homoglycans - only in plant cells; Heteroglycans - only in animal cells.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Homoglycans - repeated units of the same monosaccharide;

Heteroglycans - two or more different types of monosaccharide units.

 

Explanation:

Polysaccharides are classified into :

 

Homoglycans/ homopolysaccharides

Heteroglycans/ heteropolysaccharides
  • Made of a single kind of monosaccharide unit.

(Option A)
  • Made of two or more different monosaccharides.

(Option A)
  • Used for both structural and energy storage.

(Option B)
 
  • Used for both structural and energy storage.

(Option B)
  • Variable solubility (dextran, cellulose)

(Option C)
  • Variable solubility (agar, hyaluronic acid, keratin sulphate)

(Option C)
  • Found in both plants and animals ( starch & glycogen)

(Option D)
  • Found in both plants & animals (agar & keratan sulfate)

(Option D)
  • Ex: starch, glycogen and cellulose.
  • Ex: hyaluronic acid, chondroitin sulfate.

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, bloating, flatulence and frothy stools. It is noticed that these symptoms arise only when he consumes milk or other dairy products. Which of the following is the IOC in this situation to diagnose him?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Hydrogen breath test

 

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis here points to lactose intolerance, a digestion defect caused by the enzyme lactase deficiency.
  • It presents with symptoms like osmotic diarrhoea, flatulence, bloating, and frothy stools.
  • The investigation of choice for lactose intolerance is the Hydrogen breath test and methane breath test.

 

Other tests include:

  • Stool acidity test: Unabsorbed lactose is fermented by colonic bacteria into lactic acid, lowering stool pH.
  • Dietary elimination: Elimination of certain foods reduces the symptoms.
  • Milk tolerance test: 500ml milk to be consumed and to note the blood glucose level to see malabsorption
  • Lactose tolerance test: Checks lactose absorption after consuming a lactose-containing liquid.
  • Small intestine biopsy: Done to find secondary causes only.
  • Genotyping

questions.text: Which of the following is non-reducing sugar?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Sucrose

 

Explanation:

Non-reducing sugars are carbohydrates that lack a free aldehyde or ketone group, preventing them from acting as reducing agents.

Examples include sucrose and trehalose, where the glycosidic bond involves the reducing ends. They do not react with Benedict's or Fehling's solutions. However, after acid hydrolysis, they can be converted to reducing sugars, giving a positive result in these tests. Non-reducing sugars are significant in various biological and nutritional contexts.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient with a history of gastrointestinal issues is undergoing metabolic testing. The clinical team is investigating the role of different types of disaccharides in digestion and absorption. Which of the following are the constituent monosaccharides of the disaccharide lactose?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Glucose and Galactose

Explanation:

 

Disaccharide

Sugars present

Linkage

Maltose (Basic thumb rule)

2 glucose residues - glucose + glucose

alpha(1,4)

Isomaltose (Six atoms)

2 glucose residues - glucose + glucose

a(1,6)

Trehalose

2 glucose residues - glucose + glucose

a(1,1)

Sucrose

Glucose + fructose

a(1,2)

Lactose

Galactose + glucose

beta(1,4)
